node.text:
Meet Guy Bellingham, who uses a 170-year-old technique to make striking photos in remarkable detail. 📷 
 
Guy is a wet plate photographer and his 'Victorian Polaroid' process uses various chemicals to produce pictures that have incredible clarity and detail.
 
Mr Bellingham says the resulting image feels “like you’re capturing people’s souls and immortalising them”.

#Photo #Photography #BBCNews

node.text:
British tennis sensation Emma Raducanu has been speaking about how it felt to receive a compliment from Queen Elizabeth II after winning the US Open title.
 
In a statement, the Queen praised the 18-year-old’s “outstanding performance” and described her success as “a remarkable achievement… [that] will inspire the next generation of tennis players".
 
18-year-old Emma said she planned to celebrate beating teenager Leylah Fernandez with chocolate flavoured frozen yoghurt.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Emma's reaction to her fairy tale win in New York.

#Tennis #BBCSport #BBCNews

node.title: “It meant everything to get a message from Her Majesty.”

node.text:
Twenty years after the deadliest attacks on US soil, those who died in the 9/11 attacks have been remembered across America.
 
The official memorial in New York started with a minute's silence at the exact moment the first plane hit the North Tower of the World Trade Center in 2001.
 
There were five more moments of silence over the next few hours - marking the time when the second plane crashed into the South Tower, when a third jet struck the Pentagon just outside Washington DC, when the fourth plane crashed in Pennsylvania, and finally when each tower collapsed.
 
Tap the link in our bio to read more about the commemorations.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews

node.text:
"I live in a camp, like every refugee."

The BBC first met Wahida Faizi, an Afghan journalist attempting to flee the Taliban, at Kabul airport in August.
In an emotional interview, she said she feared that the Taliban would kill her for the work she'd done in her career as a journalist. 
A few weeks on, Wahida told the BBC what life is like for her now.

#Afghanistan #BBC

node.text:
Days after the attacks on 11 September 2001, the internet was rife with fake claims of what happened on the day.

Many were quickly dismissed as silly hoaxes, but others were rooted in racism and anti-Semitism and conspiracies of collusion by the deep state.

Twenty years later they are a powerful reminder of how the internet can be manipulated to distort the truth.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews

node.text:
“His body was found on the 23rd floor staircase.”

Some grieved, some helped and some worried.

Two decades after the terror attacks on the United States on 11 September, 2001, four people from around the world reflect on how they were affected that day, and what's changed since.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews

node.title: How the world reacted to the 9/11 terror attacks

node.text:
On 11 September 2001, at 9.03am, the second of four hijacked planes hit the South Tower of the World Trade Center in New York.

As President George W Bush met a class of seven-year-olds in Florida, the US government quickly concluded America was under attack.

With limited information, officials fought to regain control amid the chaos across the US.

The events of the day led to two decades of conflict in Afghanistan and Iraq.

Tap the link in our bio to watch the revealing documentary, 9/11: Inside the President's War Room on BBC iPlayer.

#BBCNews

node.title: Inside the President's War Room on 9/11

node.text:
Scottish veteran Pipe Major Scott Methven held the role of Queen’s piper for four years - a job often considered one of the most coveted in the piping world.

Each morning at exactly nine o’clock, he took part in a little-known ritual that takes place in grounds of where the Queen is in residence.

For 15 minutes, a lone piper in Highland uniform strikes up a selection of tunes below the monarch's window - a position called the Piper to the Sovereign.

Upon returning from service in Afghanistan, Scott was chosen to be the Queen's personal piper from 2015 to 2019.

During his service, he was "thrust into the inner circle of the monarchy", playing at countless public and private occasions entertaining royalty, celebrities and visiting heads of state.

#Bagpipes #RoyalFamily #BBCNews

node.title: My life as the Queen’s piper

node.text:
Residents reported seeing 'earthquake lights' in the sky when a magnitude-seven earthquake struck Mexico's Pacific coast.

The rare occurrence is thought to be caused by energy charges released by certain rocks during a quake.

node.text:
“I always knew racism in football existed, and hoped I wouldn’t have to come across it myself.”

The Women’s Superleague has signed a broadcast deal with the BBC and Sky - the largest commercial agreement in women’s football to date.

Anita Asante, who plays for Aston Villa, says the deal is a ‘huge opportunity to grow the sport’.

But she fears the increased exposure and boost to the profile of players may result in more online abuse, particularly towards non-white players.

#WSL #BBCNews

node.title: Could a boost to English women’s football mean more online abuse?

node.text:
Hospitals in Lebanon have had to cut back on essential services due to the worsening political and economic crisis.

Some people are experiencing power cuts of 20 hours a day, as the city is plunged into darkness due to a lack of fuel.

#Lebanon #BBCNews

node.title: "We have no water, no electricity, no nothing."

node.text:
Cat-astrophe averted. 🙀 

American football fans used a flag to catch a cat, after it fell from the stadium's upper deck.

#Cat #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 12, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'NEWS Britney Spears announces engagement to Sam Asghari'.

node.text:
Britney Spears is engaged! 💍

In a surprise Instagram post, the pop star showed off her ring to her long-term boyfriend Sam Asghari.

Asghari, who is a personal trainer and actor, posted a separate photo of the ring and the couple kissing.

The two met on the set of a music video in 2016.

Spears is fighting a legal battle to end her 13-year conservatorship, which had her father controlling her life and finances. She revealed that the terms of the arrangement were preventing her from marrying Mr Asghari or having more children.
 
Tap the link in our bio for more on this story.

(📸: Getty Images)

#BritneySpears #Engagement #BBCNews

node.text:
Meet Guy Bellingham, who uses a 170-year-old technique to make striking photos in remarkable detail. 📷 
 
Guy is a wet plate photographer and his 'Victorian Polaroid' process uses various chemicals to produce pictures that have incredible clarity and detail.
 
Mr Bellingham says the resulting image feels “like you’re capturing people’s souls and immortalising them”.

#Photo #Photography #BBCNews

node.text:
British tennis sensation Emma Raducanu has been speaking about how it felt to receive a compliment from Queen Elizabeth II after winning the US Open title.
 
In a statement, the Queen praised the 18-year-old’s “outstanding performance” and described her success as “a remarkable achievement… [that] will inspire the next generation of tennis players".
 
18-year-old Emma said she planned to celebrate beating teenager Leylah Fernandez with chocolate flavoured frozen yoghurt.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Emma's reaction to her fairy tale win in New York.

#Tennis #BBCSport #BBCNews

node.text:
Twenty years after the deadliest attacks on US soil, those who died in the 9/11 attacks have been remembered across America.
 
The official memorial in New York started with a minute's silence at the exact moment the first plane hit the North Tower of the World Trade Center in 2001.
 
There were five more moments of silence over the next few hours - marking the time when the second plane crashed into the South Tower, when a third jet struck the Pentagon just outside Washington DC, when the fourth plane crashed in Pennsylvania, and finally when each tower collapsed.
 
Tap the link in our bio to read more about the commemorations.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews

node.text:
Tennis star Emma Raducanu said she did not want to let go of the US Open trophy after she beat fellow teenager Leylah Fernandez with a stunning victory in New York.
 
The 18-year-old is the first British woman in 44 years to win a Grand Slam singles title and did not drop a set.
 
She is also the first qualifier to win a major title.
 
Tap the link in our bio to read the many messages of congratulations Emma has received including one from Queen Elizabeth II.
 
The Queen described her success as “a remarkable achievement at such a young age, and is testament to your hard work and dedication."
 
"A star is born," tennis legend Martina Navratilova said. "Emma Raducanu makes history and she is just getting started."
 
Former Wimbledon champion Pat Cash described her success as "mindboggling".
 
"This [a qualifier winning a Grand Slam] is something I never could have believed would happen," the Australian said.

(📸 Reuters/EPA/PA)

#Tennis #BBCSport #BBCNews

node.text:
18-year-old Emma Raducanu is the US Open champion.

The teenager ended Britain's 44-year wait for a women's Grand Slam singles champion as she beat Leylah Fernandez to win the US Open.

She is the first qualifier in the Open era to win a Grand Slam final, and won in straight sets, with a 6-4 6-3 win over her 19-year-old Canadian opponent.

Raducanu threw herself to the floor in disbelief as she fired down an ace to conclude what has been the most remarkable journey.

Click the link in our bio to read more about Radacanu's incredible victory, and rise to fame.

(Photos: EPA, Reuters)

#Tennis #BBCSport #BBCNews

node.text:
It is 20 years to the day since co-ordinated attacks on US landmarks killed thousands.

Emotional ceremonies were held around the US to commemorate the 9/11 attacks.
 
Relatives of victims have been reading aloud the names of their loved ones at a New York ceremony, where there have been six moments of silence to mark the times the planes crashed and buildings fell.

Thousands of people across the US have gathered to mark the sombre occasion.
 
Click the link in our bio to read some of the emotional tributes that were paid to victims.
 
(📸:EPA, Reuters, Getty)

#September11 #NewYork #BBCNews

node.text:
"I live in a camp, like every refugee."

The BBC first met Wahida Faizi, an Afghan journalist attempting to flee the Taliban, at Kabul airport in August.
In an emotional interview, she said she feared that the Taliban would kill her for the work she'd done in her career as a journalist. 
A few weeks on, Wahida told the BBC what life is like for her now.

#Afghanistan #BBC

node.text:
Days after the attacks on 11 September 2001, the internet was rife with fake claims of what happened on the day.

Many were quickly dismissed as silly hoaxes, but others were rooted in racism and anti-Semitism and conspiracies of collusion by the deep state.

Twenty years later they are a powerful reminder of how the internet can be manipulated to distort the truth.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews

node.text:
“His body was found on the 23rd floor staircase.”

Some grieved, some helped and some worried.

Two decades after the terror attacks on the United States on 11 September, 2001, four people from around the world reflect on how they were affected that day, and what's changed since.

#911 #September11 #BBCNews
